output:
Set d=n+2.  Then

 3(n+3)(n²+9)=3(d+1)((d−2)²+9)=3(d+1)(d²−4d+13)≡3·1·13=39 (mod d),

so d|39.  The positive divisors d≥3 of 39 are 3,13,39, giving n=d−2=1,11,37.  Their sum is  
1+11+37=49.  

Answer: 49.

To have \(n+2\mid 3(n+3)(n^2+9)\), set \(d=n+2\).  Then modulo \(d\), \(n\equiv-2\) so
\[
3(n+3)(n^2+9)\equiv3\cdot1\cdot13=39\pmod d.
\]
Hence \(d\mid39\), and since \(n>0\), \(d=n+2\in\{3,13,39\}\), giving \(n\in\{1,11,37\}\).  Their sum is
\[
1+11+37=49.
\]

We set k=n+2, so n=k−2 and the divisibility becomes
  k | 3(k+1)( (k−2)²+9 )=3(k+1)(k²−4k+13).
  Modulo k this is ≡3·1·13=39, hence k|39.  Since n>0⇒k≥3, the only possibilities are
  k=3,13,39 ⇒ n=1,11,37.
Thus the sum is 1+11+37=49.

We set d = n+2.  Then n = d−2 and

 3(n+3)(n²+9)
= 3(d+1)( (d−2)²+9 )
≡ 3·1·13 ≡ 39 (mod d).

Hence d∣39, so d∈{1,3,13,39}.  Since n>0 we take d=3,13,39, giving n=d−2=1,11,37.  Their sum is

1+11+37=49.

Checking each value confirms that they indeed satisfy the divisibility condition. Summing these values, we get:

\]
